mn97:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
mn97:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

mn97:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto dakkhiṇāgirismiṃ cārikaṃ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ.
mn97:2.1.eng: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was wandering in the Southern Hills together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
mn97:2.1.comm: The Southern Hills (dakkhiṇāgiri, “Deccan”) is the Vindhya Range that lies on the southern border of Magadha, leading southwest to Avanti. The Buddha and his disciples visited there so rarely that people complained (Kd 1:53.1.3). Nonetheless, the present narrative suggests that Sāriputta had stayed there for an extended period of time, long enough to lose touch with his friends back home.

mn97:2.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu rājagahe vassaṃvuṭṭho yena dakkhiṇāgiri yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn97:2.2.eng: Then a certain mendicant who had completed the rainy season residence in Rājagaha went to the Southern Hills, where he approached Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

mn97:2.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho taṃ bhikkhuṃ āyasmā sāriputto etadavoca:
mn97:2.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. Sāriputta said to him,

mn97:2.4.eng: “Reverend, I hope the Buddha is healthy and strong?”

mn97:2.6.pli: “Kacci panāvuso, bhikkhusaṅgho arogo ca balavā cā”ti?
mn97:2.6.eng: “And I hope that the mendicant Saṅgha is healthy and strong.”

mn97:2.7.pli: “Bhikkhusaṅghopi kho, āvuso, arogo ca balavā cā”ti.

mn97:2.8.pli: “Ettha, āvuso, taṇḍulapālidvārāya dhanañjāni nāma brāhmaṇo atthi.
mn97:2.8.eng: “Reverend, at the rice checkpoint at the city gate there is a brahmin named Dhanañjāni.
mn97:2.8.comm: The “rice checkpoint at the city gate” (taṇḍulapālidvārā) was a gate of Rājagaha where rice would be inspected and tolls collected. Here pāli has the sense “guard” (cp. Sanskrit pālin). This was not Dhanañjāni’s residence, but where he worked and, it would seem, skimmed off funds for his own benefit. | Kauṭilya discusses corruption among government servants (Arthaśāstra 2.9), sets out the duties of the toll collector (2.21), and lists the various tolls (2.22).

mn97:2.9.pli: Kaccāvuso, dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo arogo ca balavā cā”ti?
mn97:2.9.eng: I hope that he is healthy and strong?”

mn97:2.10.pli: “Dhanañjānipi kho, āvuso, brāhmaṇo arogo ca balavā cā”ti.

mn97:2.13.pli: Dhanañjāni, āvuso, brāhmaṇo rājānaṃ nissāya brāhmaṇagahapatike vilumpati, brāhmaṇagahapatike nissāya rājānaṃ vilumpati.
mn97:2.13.eng: Dhanañjāni robs the brahmins and householders in the name of the king, and he robs the king in the name of the brahmins and householders.
mn97:2.13.comm: Dhanañjāni is a Pali variation of the Vedic dhanañjaya, “winner of wealth”, an apt description of his activities. See too note on SN 7.1:1.3.

mn97:2.14.pli: Yāpissa bhariyā saddhā saddhakulā ānītā sāpi kālaṅkatā;
mn97:2.14.eng: His wife, a lady of faith who he married from a family of faith, has passed away.
mn97:2.14.comm: A faithful laywoman named Dhanañjānī features in MN 100 and SN 7.1, but this was a different person.

mn97:2.15.eng: And he has taken a new wife who has no faith.”

mn97:2.17.pli: ye mayaṃ dhanañjāniṃ brāhmaṇaṃ pamattaṃ assumha.
mn97:2.17.eng: to hear that Dhanañjāni is negligent.

mn97:2.18.pli: Appeva ca nāma mayaṃ kadāci karahaci dhanañjāninā brāhmaṇena saddhiṃ samāgaccheyyāma, appeva nāma siyā kocideva kathāsallāpo”ti?
mn97:2.18.eng: Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet him, and we can have a discussion.”

mn97:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto dakkhiṇāgirismiṃ yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena rājagahaṃ tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
mn97:3.1.eng: When Sāriputta had stayed in the Southern Hills as long as he pleased, he set out for Rājagaha.

mn97:3.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena rājagahaṃ tadavasari.
mn97:3.2.eng: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Rājagaha,

mn97:3.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ āyasmā sāriputto rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
mn97:3.3.eng: where he stayed in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

mn97:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya rājagahaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn97:4.1.eng: Then he robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.

mn97:4.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo bahinagare gāvo goṭṭhe duhāpeti.
mn97:4.2.eng: Now at that time Dhanañjāni was having his cows milked in a cow-shed outside the city.

mn97:4.3.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto rājagahe piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkami.
mn97:4.3.eng: Then Sāriputta wandered for alms in Rājagaha. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he approached Dhanañjāni.

mn97:4.4.pli: Addasā kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn97:4.4.eng: Seeing Sāriputta coming off in the distance,

mn97:4.5.pli: Disvāna yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn97:4.5.eng: Dhanañjāni went to him and said,

mn97:4.6.pli: “ito, bho sāriputta, payo, pīyataṃ tāva bhattassa kālo bhavissatī”ti.
mn97:4.6.eng: “Here, worthy Sāriputta, drink some fresh milk before the meal time.”

mn97:4.9.eng: I shall be at the root of that tree for the day’s meditation.

mn97:4.11.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosi.

mn97:5.1.pli: Atha kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo pacchābhattaṃ bhuttapātarāso yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn97:5.1.eng: When Dhanañjāni had finished breakfast he went to Sāriputta and exchanged greetings with him.

mn97:5.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho dhanañjāniṃ brāhmaṇaṃ āyasmā sāriputto etadavoca:
mn97:5.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. Sāriputta said to him,

mn97:5.4.pli: “Kuto, bho sāriputta, amhākaṃ appamādo yesaṃ no mātāpitaro posetabbā, puttadāro posetabbo, dāsakammakarā posetabbā, mittāmaccānaṃ mittāmaccakaraṇīyaṃ kātabbaṃ, ñātisālohitānaṃ ñātisālohitakaraṇīyaṃ kātabbaṃ, atithīnaṃ atithikaraṇīyaṃ kātabbaṃ, pubbapetānaṃ pubbapetakaraṇīyaṃ kātabbaṃ, devatānaṃ devatākaraṇīyaṃ kātabbaṃ, rañño rājakaraṇīyaṃ kātabbaṃ, ayampi kāyo pīṇetabbo brūhetabbo”ti?
mn97:5.4.eng: “How can I possibly be diligent, worthy Sāriputta? I have to provide for my mother and father, my wives and children, and my bondservants and workers. And I have to make the proper offerings to friends and colleagues, relatives and kin, guests, ancestors, deities, and king. And then this body must also be fattened and built up.”
mn97:5.4.comm: The five “proper offerings” correspond with the five to whom bali offerings are made (AN 4.61:15.2, AN 5.41:4.2). | In agreement with brūhetabbo (“to be built up”), pīṇetabbo is from pīṇa in the sense “fatten” rather than “gladden”.

mn97:6.2.pli: idhekacco mātāpitūnaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.
mn97:6.2.eng: Suppose someone was to behave in an unprincipled and unjust way for the sake of their parents. Because of this the wardens of hell would drag them to hell.

mn97:6.3.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho mātāpitūnaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, mātāpitaro vā panassa labheyyuṃ ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?
mn97:6.3.eng: Could they get out of being dragged to hell by pleading that they had acted for the sake of their parents? Or could their parents save them by pleading that the acts had been done for their sake?”

mn97:6.5.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.
mn97:6.5.eng: Rather, even as they were wailing the wardens of hell would cast them down into hell.”

mn97:7.2.pli: idhekacco puttadārassa hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.
mn97:7.2.eng: Suppose someone was to behave in an unprincipled and unjust way for the sake of their wives and children …

mn97:7.3.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho puttadārassa hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, puttadāro vā panassa labheyya ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?

mn97:7.5.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.

mn97:8.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, idhekacco dāsakammakaraporisassa hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.

mn97:8.2.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho dāsakammakaraporisassa hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, dāsakammakaraporisā vā panassa labheyyuṃ ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?

mn97:8.4.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.

mn97:9.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, idhekacco mittāmaccānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.

mn97:9.2.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho mittāmaccānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, mittāmaccā vā panassa labheyyuṃ ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?

mn97:9.4.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.

mn97:10.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, idhekacco ñātisālohitānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.

mn97:10.2.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho ñātisālohitānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, ñātisālohitā vā panassa labheyyuṃ ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?

mn97:10.4.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.

mn97:11.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, idhekacco atithīnaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.

mn97:11.2.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho atithīnaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, atithī vā panassa labheyyuṃ ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?

mn97:11.4.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.

mn97:12.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, idhekacco pubbapetānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.

mn97:12.2.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho pubbapetānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, pubbapetā vā panassa labheyyuṃ ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?

mn97:12.4.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.

mn97:13.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, idhekacco devatānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.

mn97:13.2.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho devatānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, devatā vā panassa labheyyuṃ ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?

mn97:13.4.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.

mn97:14.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, idhekacco rañño hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.

mn97:14.2.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho rañño hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, rājā vā panassa labheyya ‘eso kho amhākaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?

mn97:14.4.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.

mn97:15.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, idhekacco kāyassa pīṇanāhetu brūhanāhetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, tamenaṃ adhammacariyāvisamacariyāhetu nirayaṃ nirayapālā upakaḍḍheyyuṃ.
mn97:15.1.eng: fattening and building up their body. Because of this the wardens of hell would drag them to hell.

mn97:15.2.pli: Labheyya nu kho so ‘ahaṃ kho kāyassa pīṇanāhetu brūhanāhetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosiṃ, mā maṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’ti, pare vā panassa labheyyuṃ ‘eso kho kāyassa pīṇanāhetu brūhanāhetu adhammacārī visamacārī ahosi, mā naṃ nirayaṃ nirayapālā’”ti?
mn97:15.2.eng: Could they get out of being dragged to hell by pleading that they had acted for the sake of fattening and building up their body? Or could anyone else save them by pleading that the acts had been done for that reason?”

mn97:15.4.pli: Atha kho naṃ vikkandantaṃyeva niraye nirayapālā pakkhipeyyuṃ”.
mn97:15.4.eng: Rather, even as they were wailing the wardens of hell would cast them down into hell.”

mn97:16.1.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā mātāpitūnaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā mātāpitūnaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;
mn97:16.1.eng: “Who do you think is better, Dhanañjāni? Someone who, for the sake of their parents, behaves in an unprincipled and unjust manner, or someone who behaves in a principled and just manner?”

mn97:16.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, mātāpitūnaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;
mn97:16.3.eng: “Someone who behaves in a principled and just manner for the sake of their parents.

mn97:16.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, mātāpitūnaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:16.5.eng: For principled and moral conduct is better than unprincipled and immoral conduct.”

mn97:16.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā mātāpitaro ceva posetuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.
mn97:16.6.eng: “Dhanañjāni, others have livelihoods that are both profitable and legitimate. By means of these it’s possible to provide for your parents, avoid bad deeds, and practice the path of goodness.

mn97:17.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā puttadārassa hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā puttadārassa hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;
mn97:17.1.eng: Who do you think is better, Dhanañjāni? Someone who, for the sake of their wives and children …

mn97:17.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, puttadārassa hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;

mn97:17.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, puttadārassa hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:17.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā yehi sakkā puttadārañceva posetuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.

mn97:18.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā dāsakammakaraporisassa hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā dāsakammakaraporisassa hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;

mn97:18.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, dāsakammakaraporisassa hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;

mn97:18.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, dāsakammakaraporisassa hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:18.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā dāsakammakaraporise ceva posetuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.

mn97:19.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā mittāmaccānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā mittāmaccānaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;

mn97:19.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, mittāmaccānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;

mn97:19.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, mittāmaccānaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:19.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā mittāmaccānañceva mittāmaccakaraṇīyaṃ kātuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.

mn97:20.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā ñātisālohitānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā ñātisālohitānaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;

mn97:20.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, ñātisālohitānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;

mn97:20.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, ñātisālohitānaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:20.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā ñātisālohitānañceva ñātisālohitakaraṇīyaṃ kātuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.

mn97:21.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā atithīnaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā atithīnaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;

mn97:21.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, atithīnaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;

mn97:21.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, atithīnaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:21.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā atithīnañceva atithikaraṇīyaṃ kātuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.

mn97:22.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā pubbapetānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā pubbapetānaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;

mn97:22.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, pubbapetānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;

mn97:22.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, pubbapetānaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:22.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā pubbapetānañceva pubbapetakaraṇīyaṃ kātuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.

mn97:23.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā devatānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā devatānaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;

mn97:23.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, devatānaṃ hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;

mn97:23.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, devatānaṃ hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:23.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā devatānañceva devatākaraṇīyaṃ kātuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.

mn97:24.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā rañño hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā rañño hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;

mn97:24.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, rañño hetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;

mn97:24.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, rañño hetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:24.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā rañño ceva rājakaraṇīyaṃ kātuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjituṃ.

mn97:25.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, dhanañjāni, yo vā kāyassa pīṇanāhetu brūhanāhetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, yo vā kāyassa pīṇanāhetu brūhanāhetu dhammacārī samacārī assa;
mn97:25.1.eng: fattening and building up their body, behaves in an unprincipled and unjust manner, or someone who behaves in a principled and just manner?”

mn97:25.3.pli: “Yo hi, bho sāriputta, kāyassa pīṇanāhetu brūhanāhetu adhammacārī visamacārī assa, na taṃ seyyo;
mn97:25.3.eng: “Someone who behaves in a principled and just manner.

mn97:25.4.pli: yo ca kho, bho sāriputta, kāyassa pīṇanāhetu brūhanāhetu dhammacārī samacārī assa, tadevettha seyyo.

mn97:25.5.eng: For principled and moral conduct is better than unprincipled and immoral conduct.”

mn97:25.6.pli: “Atthi kho, dhanañjāni, aññesaṃ hetukā dhammikā kammantā, yehi sakkā kāyañceva pīṇetuṃ brūhetuṃ, na ca pāpakammaṃ kātuṃ, puññañca paṭipadaṃ paṭipajjitun”ti.
mn97:25.6.eng: “Dhanañjāni, others have livelihoods that are both profitable and legitimate. By means of these it’s possible to fatten and build up your body, avoid bad deeds, and practice the path of goodness.”

mn97:26.1.pli: Atha kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo āyasmato sāriputtassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
mn97:26.1.eng: Then Dhanañjāni the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what Venerable Sāriputta said, got up from his seat and left.

mn97:27.1.pli: Atha kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo aparena samayena ābādhiko ahosi dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
mn97:27.1.eng: Some time later Dhanañjāni became sick, suffering, gravely ill.

mn97:27.2.pli: Atha kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo aññataraṃ purisaṃ āmantesi:

mn97:27.3.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, ambho purisa, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi:
mn97:27.3.eng: “Please, worthy man, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

mn97:27.4.eng: ‘Sir, the brahmin Dhanañjāni is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

mn97:27.5.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’

mn97:27.6.pli: Yena cāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena āyasmato sāriputtassa pāde sirasā vandāhi:
mn97:27.6.eng: Then go to Venerable Sāriputta, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:

mn97:27.7.eng: ‘Sir, the brahmin Dhanañjāni is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

mn97:27.8.pli: So āyasmato sāriputtassa pāde sirasā vandatī’ti.
mn97:27.8.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’

mn97:27.10.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, āyasmā sāriputto yena dhanañjānissa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.
mn97:27.10.eng: ‘Sir, please visit Dhanañjāni at his home out of sympathy.’”

mn97:27.11.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so puriso dhanañjānissa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so puriso bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn97:27.11.eng: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Dhanañjāni asked.

mn97:27.14.pli: Yena cāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so puriso āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:

mn97:27.16.pli: So āyasmato sāriputtassa pāde sirasā vandati, evañca vadeti:

mn97:27.17.pli: ‘sādhu kira, bhante, āyasmā sāriputto yena dhanañjānissa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā’”ti.

mn97:28.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena dhanañjānissa brāhmaṇassa nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Nisajja kho āyasmā sāriputto dhanañjāniṃ brāhmaṇaṃ etadavoca:
mn97:28.1.eng: He robed up, and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Dhanañjāni’s home, where he sat on the seat spread out and said to Dhanañjāni,

mn97:28.2.pli: “kacci te, dhanañjāni, khamanīyaṃ, kacci yāpanīyaṃ? Kacci dukkhā vedanā paṭikkamanti, no abhikkamanti? Paṭikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no abhikkamo”ti?
mn97:28.2.eng: “I hope you’re keeping well, Dhanañjāni; I hope you’re all right. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”

mn97:29.1.pli: “Na me, bho sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti. Abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.
mn97:29.1.eng: “I’m not keeping well, worthy Sāriputta, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.

mn97:29.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho sāriputta, balavā puriso tiṇhena sikharena muddhani abhimattheyya; evameva kho, bho sāriputta, adhimattā vātā muddhani ca ūhananti.
mn97:29.2.eng: The winds piercing my head are so severe, it feels like a strong man drilling into my head with a sharp point.

mn97:29.3.pli: Na me, bho sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ, na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti. Abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

mn97:29.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho sāriputta, balavā puriso daḷhena varattakkhaṇḍena sīse sīsaveṭhaṃ dadeyya; evameva kho, bho sāriputta, adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā.
mn97:29.4.eng: The pain in my head is so severe, it feels like a strong man tightening a strong leather strap around my head.

mn97:29.5.pli: Na me, bho sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti. Abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

mn97:29.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho sāriputta, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā tiṇhena govikantanena kucchiṃ parikanteyya; evameva kho, bho sāriputta, adhimattā vātā kucchiṃ parikantanti.
mn97:29.6.eng: The winds slicing my belly are so severe, like a deft butcher or their apprentice were slicing open a cows’s belly with a sharp meat cleaver.

mn97:29.7.pli: Na me, bho sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ, na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti. Abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo.

mn97:29.8.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho sāriputta, dve balavanto purisā dubbalataraṃ purisaṃ nānābāhāsu gahetvā aṅgārakāsuyā santāpeyyuṃ samparitāpeyyuṃ; evameva kho, bho sāriputta, adhimatto kāyasmiṃ ḍāho.
mn97:29.8.eng: The burning in my body is so severe, it feels like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.

mn97:29.9.pli: Na me, bho sāriputta, khamanīyaṃ na yāpanīyaṃ. Bāḷhā me dukkhā vedanā abhikkamanti, no paṭikkamanti. Abhikkamosānaṃ paññāyati, no paṭikkamo”ti.
mn97:29.9.eng: I’m not keeping well, worthy Sāriputta, I’m not getting by. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”

mn97:30.1.eng: “Dhanañjāni, which do you think is better:

mn97:30.5.eng: the animal realm or the ghost realm?”

mn97:30.8.eng: the ghost realm or human life?”

mn97:30.11.eng: human life or as one of the gods of the four great kings?”

mn97:30.12.eng: “The gods of the four great kings.”
mn97:30.12.comm: The “gods of the four great kings” (cātumahārājikā devā) are deities born in a realm subject to the overlords known as the Four Great Kings: Kuvera (also called Vessavaṇa) lord of spirits (yakkha) in the north; Dhataraṭṭha lord of centaurs (gandhabba) in the east; Virūḷha lord of goblins (kumbhaṇḍa) in the south; and Virūpakkha lord of dragons (nāga) in the west (see DN 32). Sanskrit sources sometimes multiply their number to eight (eg. Śivapurāṇa 2.2.22.43).

mn97:30.14.pli: cātumahārājikā vā devā tāvatiṃsā vā devā”ti?
mn97:30.14.eng: the gods of the four great kings or the gods of the thirty-three?”

mn97:30.15.pli: “Cātumahārājikehi, bho sāriputta, devehi tāvatiṃsā devā seyyo”ti.
mn97:30.15.comm: The “gods of the thirty-three” (tāvatiṁsā devā), who are subjects of Sakka (also called Indra), enjoy refined sensual delights. The number is a reduplication of the trinity. In Buddhist texts they are not enumerated, but Yājñavalkya reckons them as eight Vasus, eleven Rudras, twelve Ādityas, plus Indra and Prajāpati (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.9.2). The final pair are elsewhere said to be Dyaus (“Heaven” = Zeus) and Pṛthivī (“Earth”), or the twin Aśvins.

mn97:30.17.pli: tāvatiṃsā vā devā yāmā vā devā”ti?
mn97:30.17.eng: the gods of the thirty-three or the gods of Yama?”

mn97:30.18.pli: “Tāvatiṃsehi, bho sāriputta, devehi yāmā devā seyyo”ti.
mn97:30.18.comm: Gods in this realm (spelled yāma, “of Yama”) are subjects of Yama, the god who guards the paths to the land of the dead (SN 1.33:10.3, MN 130:3.1, Dhp 235). He was the son of Vivasvant (the sun) and brother of Manu, and as the first person to die, Rig Veda 10.4 tells us that he discovered the paths to the lands of the dead that he now guards with his pair of hounds. Yama is a righteous god, but sinners see him as horrifying due to their own guilt (Brahma Purāṇa 106.46).

mn97:30.20.pli: yāmā vā devā tusitā vā devā”ti?
mn97:30.20.eng: the gods of Yama or the joyful gods?”

mn97:30.21.pli: “Yāmehi, bho sāriputta, devehi tusitā devā seyyo”ti.
mn97:30.21.comm: The “joyful gods” (tusitā devā) were known to the Jains, who classed them among the gods of the world’s end (lokāntika; Tattvārthasūtra 4.25; Viyāhapaṇṇatti 5.3.95). Later Hindu tradition says they were the sons of Kaśyapa through Aditi, otherwise known as the twelve Ādityas: Viṣṇu, Śakra, Tvaṣṭṛ, Dhātṛ, Aryaman, Pūṣan, Vivasvat, Savitṛ, Mitra, Varuṇa, Bhaga, and Aṁśu. (Agnipurāṇa 19.1–3, Liṅgapurāṇa 63.22b–26). In Buddhism, this realm is famed as the final home of Bodhisattas before they descend to the human realm to become Buddhas.

mn97:30.23.pli: tusitā vā devā nimmānaratī vā devā”ti?
mn97:30.23.eng: the joyful gods or the gods who love to create?”

mn97:30.24.pli: “Tusitehi, bho sāriputta, devehi nimmānaratī devā seyyo”ti.
mn97:30.24.comm: These deities (nimmānaratī devā) are said to create whatever delights they wish and enjoy them, living in a world of their own projection. They seem to be primarily Buddhist, perhaps influenced by such passages as Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.9, which says that in dreams one creates (svayaṁ nirmāya) a new reality that is revealed by one’s inner light. They are, however, mentioned in later texts such as Viṣṇu Purāṇa 3.2.30 as one of three groups of thirty, and Mārkaṇḍeyapurāṇa 44, which adds that they preside over the months, seasons, and days.

mn97:30.26.pli: nimmānaratī vā devā paranimmitavasavattī vā devā”ti?
mn97:30.26.eng: the gods who love to create or the gods who control what is created by others?”

mn97:30.27.pli: “Nimmānaratīhi, bho sāriputta, devehi paranimmitavasavattī devā seyyo”ti.
mn97:30.27.eng: “The gods who control what is created by others.”
mn97:30.27.comm: Deities in this, the highest of the sensual realms, control the visions seen by others (paranimmitavasavattī). Their most famous member is Māra, who uses this skill for wicked ends. Again they seem primarily Buddhist, although we probably hear an echo of them in Mahābhārata 12,325.004E, which lists the parinirmita and vaśavartin as two separate groups.

mn97:31.2.eng: the gods who control what is created by others or the realm of divinity?”

mn97:31.3.eng: “Worthy Sāriputta speaks of the realm of divinity!

mn97:31.4.eng: Worthy Sāriputta speaks of the realm of divinity!”

mn97:31.6.eng: “These brahmins are devoted to the realm of divinity.

mn97:31.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ dhanañjānissa brāhmaṇassa brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggaṃ deseyyan”ti.
mn97:31.7.eng: Why don’t I teach him a path to the company of Divinity?”

mn97:31.8.eng: “Dhanañjāni, I shall teach you a path to the company of Divinity.

mn97:31.9.pli: taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn97:31.9.eng: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn97:31.10.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosi.

mn97:32.1.eng: “And what is a path to company with Divinity?
mn97:32.1.comm: While it is possible to be reborn in even the highest of the sensual realms through the power of ordinary goodness, rebirth in the Brahmā and higher realms requires the development of absorption meditation.

mn97:32.2.pli: Idha, dhanañjāni, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
mn97:32.2.eng: Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

mn97:32.3.pli: Ayaṃ kho, dhanañjāni, brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggo.
mn97:32.3.eng: This is a path to company with Divinity.

mn97:33-35.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, dhanañjāni, bhikkhu karuṇāsahagatena cetasā …pe…
mn97:33-35.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …

mn97:33-35.2.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …

mn97:33-35.3.pli: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ, tathā catutthaṃ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
mn97:33-35.3.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

mn97:33-35.4.pli: Ayaṃ kho, dhanañjāni, brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggo”ti.
mn97:33-35.4.eng: This is a path to company with Divinity.”

mn97:36.1.pli: “Tena hi, bho sāriputta, mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi:
mn97:36.1.eng: “Well then, worthy Sāriputta, in my name bow with your head at the Buddha’s feet. Say to him:

mn97:36.2.eng: ‘Sir, the brahmin Dhanañjāni is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

mn97:36.3.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.’”

mn97:36.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto dhanañjāniṃ brāhmaṇaṃ sati uttarikaraṇīye hīne brahmaloke patiṭṭhāpetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
mn97:36.4.eng: Then Sāriputta, after establishing Dhanañjāni in the inferior realm of divinity, got up from his seat and left while there was still more left to do.

mn97:36.5.pli: Atha kho dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo acirapakkante āyasmante sāriputte kālamakāsi, brahmalokañca upapajji.
mn97:36.5.eng: Not long after Sāriputta had leave, Dhanañjāni passed away and was reborn in the realm of divinity.

mn97:37.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

mn97:37.2.pli: “eso, bhikkhave, sāriputto dhanañjāniṃ brāhmaṇaṃ sati uttarikaraṇīye hīne brahmaloke patiṭṭhāpetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti.
mn97:37.2.eng: “Mendicants, Sāriputta, after establishing Dhanañjāni in the inferior realm of divinity, got up from his seat and left while there was still more left to do.”

mn97:38.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi, ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn97:38.1.eng: Then Sāriputta went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said,

mn97:38.2.eng: “Sir, the brahmin Dhanañjāni is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

mn97:38.3.eng: He bows with his head to your feet.”

mn97:38.4.pli: “Kiṃ pana tvaṃ, sāriputta, dhanañjāniṃ brāhmaṇaṃ sati uttarikaraṇīye hīne brahmaloke patiṭṭhāpetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti?
mn97:38.4.eng: “But Sāriputta, after establishing Dhanañjāni in the inferior realm of divinity, why did you get up from your seat and leave while there was still more left to do?”

mn97:38.6.pli: ‘ime kho brāhmaṇā brahmalokādhimuttā, yannūnāhaṃ dhanañjānissa brāhmaṇassa brahmānaṃ sahabyatāya maggaṃ deseyyan’”ti.
mn97:38.6.eng: ‘These brahmins are devoted to the realm of divinity. Why don’t I teach him a path to the company of Divinity?’”

mn97:38.7.pli: “Kālaṅkato ca, sāriputta, dhanañjāni brāhmaṇo, brahmalokañca upapanno”ti.
mn97:38.7.eng: “And Sāriputta, the brahmin Dhanañjāni has passed away and been reborn in the realm of divinity.”
mn97:38.7.comm: This is a rare instance of someone taking rebirth due to deathbed kamma. Presumably Dhanañjāni had developed absorption based on the divine meditations, which overpowered the limited bad kamma he had made previously (MN 99:24.3). Another instance of kamma at death influencing rebirth is found at SN 42.3:2.7, where a warrior who dies in battle goes to hell. In Theravada circles today, it is commonly held that one’s mental state at death determines one’s rebirth. These examples show that this is true only in exceptional cases where one is actively making strong good or bad kamma at that time.
